newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Shenzhen B index ends higher on economic forecast.
newsitem.headline: Shenzhen B index ends higher on economic forecast.

text.p: Shenzhen's B shares ended higher on Tuesday with investor confidence bolstered by Beijing's positive economic forecast for the first half of 1997, brokers said.
The hard currency B share index rose 3.06 points or 1.69 percent to close at 184.20 on turnover of HK$263.7 million, compared with Monday's HK$253.9 million.

China's gross domestic product is expected to grow 9.6 percent year-on-year in the first half, with retail price inflation seen at two percent, the Beijing-based Financial News reported on Tuesday, quoting a forecast by the State Economic and Trade Commission.
"The new economic data fuelled optimism over China's stock markets," an analyst with a major Chinese brokerage said.

Responding to the forecasts, the Shenzhen's domestic A share index surged 17.33 points or 3.41 percent to end at a historic high of 525.21, brokers said. Turnover was a massive 19.83 billion yuan against Monday's 16.90 billion yuan.
"Concerns over listed firms' 1996 annual results have disappeared with the end of the yearly reporting season on April 30," an analyst at China Guotai Securities said.
"Investors are eyeing 1997 interim earnings, expecting high returns due to China's dynamic economy," the analyst said.
New listings in Shenzhen scheduled for later this month are expected to further boost sentiment and push the B index above the 200-point level, analysts said.

Pesticide maker Hubei Sanonda Co Ltd, Shandong Chenming Paper Holdings Ltd and Nanjing Posts & Telecommunications Equipment Co Ltd have announced they will each offer 100 million B shares for listing later this month.
"The three firms are expected to post strong debuts on listing because of their solid earnings and the market's recent bullishness," an analyst at Shenzhen J&A Securities said.
"Expected strong debuts will in turn boost the B share index," the J&A analyst said.
Shenzhen Gintian was the best performer on the B share market, after the conglomerate announced a plan to buy a domestic power plant for 80.94 million yuan.
The counter soared HK$0.33 or 8.68 percent to HK$4.13 on volume of 983,588 shares.
"Investors bought Gintian anticipating the acquisition will boost its operations in the long term," the Guotai analyst said.
"But I think investors seems to be too enthusiastic about the plan," the analyst said, citing Gintian's 1996 net loss of 62.10 million yuan under international accounting standards.
Gintian's A shares hit their 10 percent limit up at 11.70 yuan soon after afternoon trading started and stayed at that level for the rest of the session.
The A share market leader was Shenzhen Development Bank, which surged 10 percent to 44.47 yuan on volume of 29.60 million shares. Shenzhen Development Bank was also the most actively traded counter.
The bank's sharp gains followed a report in the Shenzhen-based Securities Times on Monday which quoted bank president He Yun as forecasting a strong rise in the firm's 1997 earnings.
